item.title: Protesters Call for Pakistani Premier to Step Down
item.description: Led by Imran Khan, the opposition leader and former cricket star, thousands of protesters marched from Lahore, Pakistan, demanding the resignation of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:credit: Aamir Qureshi/Agence France-Presse â€” Getty Images
item.media:description: Muhammad Tahir-ul Qadri, a Sufi cleric, led a crowd of protesters into the capital.

item.title: With Subway in the Sky, Valley Meets Plateau
item.description: La Paz, the Bolivian capital, has always looked down on El Alto, its upstart younger sibling on a plateau above. But a new mass-transit cable-car system may change that.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: Minibuses in traffic in El Alto. A cable-car ride will cost about twice as much, but some commuters say the convenience is worth it.

item.title: Eroni Kumana, Who Saved Kennedy and His Shipwrecked Crew, Dies at 96
item.description: Mr. Kumana and a fellow boatman were credited with spotting and rescuing Navy Lt. John F. Kennedy and members of his PT-109 crew after their boat had been destroyed in the Solomon Islands.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL VITELLO
item.media:credit: Melissa Armstrong/Agence France-Presse â€” Getty Images
item.media:description: Eroni Kumana, left, in an undated photograph, holding a bust of President John F. Kennedy.

item.title: 35 Are Found as Container Is Unloaded Near London
item.description: One man among those who reached England in a shipping container from Belgium has died, and the police said a homicide investigation was underway.
item.dc:creator: By DANNY HAKIM
item.media:credit: C. Villemain/Agence France-Presse â€” Getty Images
item.media:description: Police officers guarded an entrance at Tilbury docks in Essex on Saturday.

item.title: Opinion: A Choice Between Boredom and Blood
item.description: How repressive Russian regimes keep their people in line.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By SERGEY KUZNETSOV
item.media:description: Children playing on a statue of the Soviet statesman Mikhail Ivanovich Kalinin in 1991.

item.title: Plight of Iraqi Minorities Worsens With Forced Conversions and Killings
item.description: Scores of people are thought to have been killed by extremist gunmen in one village in northern Iraq after refusing to convert to Islam, an incident likely to heighten international concern about the plight of Iraqâ€™s Yazidi minority.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Kurdish soldier stood guard at a spot overlooking ISIS positions in northern Iraq.

item.title: Reporter's Notebook: On a Helicopter, Going Down: Inside a Lethal Crash in Iraq
item.description: Alissa J. Rubin, a veteran Times foreign correspondent, was injured Tuesday in a helicopter crash in Kurdistan and dictated this article from her hospital bed in Istanbul.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alissa J. Rubin, a Times reporter, on the left, and Vian Dakhil, a Yazidi lawmaker.

item.title: With Aid Doctors Gone, Ebola Fight Grows Harder
item.description: The departure of many Western development workers from the West African countries hit hardest by Ebola has further weakened the regionâ€™s decrepit, understaffed health systems.
item.dc:creator: By SHERI FINK
item.media:description: A Liberian health worker disinfected the corpse of an Ebola victim.

item.title: Deadly Attacks in Central Africa
item.description: A local official in the Central African Republic says at least 34 people have been killed by rebels in remote villages in the past week.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Floods and Landslides Kill Dozens and Leave Scores Missing in Nepal
item.description: More than 50 people died and scores are missing after three days of continuous monsoon rains contributed to floods and landslides near the Indian border.
item.dc:creator: By BHADRA SHARMA and GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: In Chinaâ€™s Shadow, U.S. Courts Old Foe Vietnam
item.description: Increasingly at loggerheads with China, the United States now envisions Vietnam as a new partner that will acquire American weapons and help offset Chinaâ€™s power.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, center, reviewed a Vietnamese honor guard in Hanoi on Thursday.

item.title: Papal Visit That Thrills Catholics Is Unsettling to Protestants in South Korea
item.description: Hundreds of thousands cheered the pope in downtown Seoul, but not everyone has welcomed him to a country where the church has vied for followers with Protestant groups.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Pope Francis in Seoul, South Korea, on Saturday, where 124 Korean Catholics who were martyred in the 18th and 19th centuries were beatified.

item.title: 3 Liberian Health Workers With Ebola Receive Scarce Drug After Appeals to U.S.
item.description: Liberian officials requested the ZMapp serum for three health workers after it was provided to two Americans who contracted Ebola while working at a hospital near Monrovia.
item.dc:creator: By SHERI FINK

item.title: Resisting Nazis, He Saw Need for Israel. Now He Is Its Critic.
item.description: Henk Zanoli, 91, who saved a Jewish boy in 1943, said he could not keep the award he received from Israel after six relatives of his grandnieceâ€™s Palestinian husband were killed in Gaza last month.
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTOPHER F. SCHUETZE and ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Henk Zanoli, second from right, with his family in 1942. A year later, he smuggled a Jewish boy from Amsterdam to the familyâ€™s home in a Dutch village and helped hide him through the war.

item.title: Agencies Issue Warnings Over Bogus Ebola Cures
item.description: The World Health Organization and the Food and Drug Administration warn some makers of dietary supplements to stop claiming their products will heal Ebola victims.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:credit: Carl De Souza/Agence France-Presse â€” Getty Images
item.media:description: A government burial team in Sierra Leone. As Ebola claims more victims, false cures are being marketed toward Africans.

item.title: With Ebola Cases Still Few, Populous Nigeria Has Chance to Halt Its Outbreak
item.description: Health officials are watching Lagos, the metropolis where all of Nigeriaâ€™s Ebola cases have been reported, with intense interest.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By DENISE GRADY
item.media:description: An Ebola isolation ward in Monrovia, Liberia. Nigeria hopes to wipe out the disease before it spirals out of control, as it has in Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone.

item.title: Quick History: Ferguson, Robin Williams and the Russian Convoy
item.description: This week police outfitted like Marines confronted demonstrators in Ferguson, Mo., a strange convoy headed to Ukraine and the world mourned the loss of a gifted comedian.
item.dc:creator: By SERGE SCHMEMANN
item.media:description: A Russian convoy of trucks carrying humanitarian aid for Ukraine travels along a road near Voronezh.

item.title: Condemned but Undeterred, Boko Haram Is Still Abducting Nigerian Youths
item.description: The militant group continues to make gains, planting bombs in cities and taking over towns, largely unchecked by an army ravaged by what diplomats say are corruption and morale problems.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: News Analysis: As World Boils, Fingers Point Obamaâ€™s Way
item.description: Buffeted by international instability, the president stresses that there are limits to American power, and that the chief executive is not omnipotent.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: Robert Richards, Marine Guilty in Taliban Desecration, Dies at 28
item.description: Mr. Richards was a sergeant who was demoted after video footage surfaced of him and his colleagues urinating on corpses of Taliban fighters in Afghanistan.

item.title: In an Iraqi Town Hollowed Out by Jihadists, There Is No Going Back to How It Was
item.description: Nearly a week after American airstrikes paved the way for Kurdish forces to reclaim Mahmour from the Sunni militants of ISIS, very few people have returned.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: Ukraine, Eye on Convoy, Says It Hit Military Vehicles Coming From Russia
item.description: NATO and Ukraine said vehicles crossed into Ukraine and were destroyed by Ukrainian artillery fire, but it was unclear whether they were carrying separatists or Russian soldiers.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Dmitry Serebryakov/Agence France-Presse â€” Getty Images
item.media:description: A convoy of trucks said to be carrying aid await inspection in the town of Kamensk-Shakhtinsky, Russia, near the Ukrainian border.

item.title: Opposition in Pakistan Is Drenched but Not Doused
item.description: Tens of thousands of opposition supporters converged on the capital in an attempt to force Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif to resign after just 14 months in office.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD and DECLAN WALSH

item.title: Spain Suspects Morocco Allowed a Brief Flood of Migrants
item.description: Spanish analysts believe that the influx of Africans to Spainâ€™s borders was orchestrated by its neighbor across the Strait of Gibraltar.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Laura Leon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Some migrants rested while others lined up for processing at a sports center in Tarifa, Spain, after hundreds were intercepted in the Strait of Gibraltar.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Remembering Pierre Ryckmans
item.description: Pierre Ryckmans, who wrote under the pen name Simon Leys and was one of the worldâ€™s pre-eminent scholars of Chinese art, literature and culture, died on Monday in Sydney, Australia.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:credit: William West/Agence France-Presse â€” Getty Images
item.media:description: Pierre Ryckmans at his home in Canberra, Australia, on Apr. 1, 1998.
